div.p: Yours of the 18 recd I hope you will be careful about our boy climbing the large trees he is not yet strong enough to trust to his arms and may get a bad fall tell him Pa dont want his boy hurt and as he is little he must only climb the little trees and that he must mind his mama or papa wont love him I saw Mrs Taylor this morning she found me out as I could not find her. Ewing has been in town but did not call to see me. I think I shall leave this about the middle of July or possibly sooner as I think the Treasury is about played out everyone thinks I can make money by practicing law here but I do not like the climate however I think I shall have to try it next winter as I have a larger acquaintance here than anywhere else and the climate will suit you and the children. I hope

you got the money I sent you by Genl Orme last week as there was too much to lose my duties are much lighter since the 20 when all trade East of the Miss River was declared free and no proof of the growth of cotton required only Arkansas and a part of Louisiana are now in my district and on some days there is nothing to do so I sit in the office and try to keep cool the weather is near pleasant and as we have had a good deal of rain the dust not so bad I am very well again but since I have less work I think of you more and get restless and fell as if I must go home at once. I wrote to Charlie to day telling her to come down on Thursday as there is no boat on friday and she can stay untill I go up Kiss all for me.
